commentBody: Easy revealer, and rebuses. Better editing was needed to make this feel like a proper Thursday puzzle. This has been another let-down.

Love me some rebuses, and this had potential, but that big reveal was clued too weakly.
Still, there were some stumpers. Nice puzzle, I enjoyed it.
Easier than I expected. I was surprised to hear the happy music. Now I can go to bed early!
I'm not a fan of gimmick puzzles, but the revealing clue gave it away early on and then I knew how to cram in the answers I had known but didn't know how to fit.

Boy, I enjoy a rebus, and figuring out the gimmick was fun, I would rather an enjoyable grid than anything else. I sometimes wonder if these sorts of themes ultimately detract from the puzzle. Outside of clues involving those eight rebuses, the rest of the puzzle involved more cramped sections and uninteresting fill than I would like (not to mention the absolute deluge of proper nouns). I don't know, this one felt like it missed the forest for a handful of really well crafted trees.

I knew that walls could have eyes, and I suppose it makes sense that they could have ears

Can they have noses? Do they taste? Do they feel?

Obviously all this AI talk recently has me questioning what human existence is

re: 27A - The answer should be PINS (or the clue rewritten to something like, ‚ÄúPresent seemingly clear but false advantages for an opponent to move to certain squares, only to their detriment, as a chess piece.‚Äù)
What a fun puzzle! I figured out 7D and knew there was probably a rebus involved. Very clever.
This was a fun one for me; the northeast corner was where I figured out the rebus situation, and it all came together pretty quickly from there!

Rebuses:

I suppose most people know this, but it can‚Äôt hurt to state it again, to wit, there is no need to utilize the ‚Äòrebus‚Äô button, just put the first of the letters to be entered in the square and move on: the program will credit you with knowing what you‚Äôre about. HETTOHET may look bizarre, but this works and it makes an onerous slog in a puzzle like today‚Äôs into ‚Äòa walk in the park.‚Äô

[I solve in the iOs version of the NYT Games app, but I have to believe the scoring algorithm is the same in all interfaces.]
7D was easy and made for a fun and quick solve.  1D, 16A and 48A deviate from the ‚Äúhow to build a crossword‚Äù guidance about repeating answers.  46D was a great answer.

Dunno why, but just wasn't a fan of this. It felt like a lot of clues (especially in the southwest section of the grid) were just names or references to things, and I was kind of out of luck and natick-ed hard from simply not knowing them. Maybe other people would've better luck, but I'm just not really enthused about so many proper nouns crossing.

That said, I did like the theme and rebus, so there is that.

The mechanics of having to enter the rebuses took me longer than having to think of the answers to the super-easy clues. Sort of like how they say Mozart composed in his head faster than he could write the notes down on paper. I have something in common with Mozart!

I solve on a PC (yes, technologically only slightly more advanced than the stone-tablet-chisel brigade).  I've never noticed this before, perhaps because many rebus puzzles have different rebuses in each rebus square.  But after I typed in the first EAR (or maybe the first two), each time I clicked on Rebus and typed the initial E, a bubble appeared with the entire rebus.  I hit return and the whole EAR filled in.  Kinda cool.  I don't know if it's a new feature, or it's always been there, but it tickled me. Speed solvers probably only ever type that first letter anyway, but I need the whole picture.

Y'all know if it's always been this way?

Smiling ear to ear after this one.  Fun and just tricky enough, with no tEARs shed.

Thank you Royce, and congratulations on your Thursday first.  You're a dEAR!


 (This üåΩ is for you, Emu!)

We didn‚Äôt start the fire, it was always burning since the world‚Äôs been turning‚Ä¶

‚ÄúEver given SUEZ!‚Äù

Thanks, once I caught that error, that song popped into my head and it goes on and on and on and on‚Ä¶

If I were a gymnastics judge I might take a few decimal points off for having to resort to repetition twice in the themes, but it definitely stuck the landing. Even getting the revealer EARly and the rebus gimmick, there was still a fair challenge and some fun clues. I think ‚Äúodd duck‚Äù for DECOY ought to be one of the best clues of the week.

I took a moment, before coming to the comments, to JIVE to DURAN Duran's "A View to a Kill." I saw them in concert last year, and they were outstanding. https://youtu.be/Fp4CR2HcHLQ?feature=shared (Thank you for including them in the puzzle, Mr. Ferguson. And a shout out to Deb for sneaking Outlander into the column. I just binge watched seasons 6 and 7 and am still high on it!) As a whole, I had a great time with this grid, figuring out where the EARs went on the walls once I got the revealer. There was an ease to the clueing and fill, which I found appealing. It made for a very smooth and delightful solve. Thank you, Mr. Ferguson, and congratulations on your first Thursday. BRAVO!

WEARANDTEAR gave away the gimmick for me instantly. Was confused since I'm pretty well versed in landmark SCOTUS Cases and couldn't remember a case involving a Mr. or Mrs. Janeroa. Didn't see the parsing until I went to Google it after solving
Not a fan of gimmicks, but since 'ear' was almost a gimme, I'll not complain.
Am I the only one who thinks 8 answers starting with "J" is pretty cool?

I do think maybe at least Thursdays are getting easier‚Äîthe only trouble I had was the cross of Ivey and TCBY, whatever that is. But I had all but the Y so I took a wild guess and got the music (well not actually, I have my sound off, but I can hear it in my head). The revealer was a big help in filling in the sides. Fun and clever. I liked the clues for acne and decoy. I thought of Dewey, he was a bit odd.

You know what else fits at 45D? Lehnmans, which actually worked briefly until I figured out what was going on with the rebuses.
And that there were two possible California Harveys, Milk and MUDD. 

It seems to me that as time has gone on that hints that a rebus puzzle is afoot have become broader. 

Finally,  I enjoyed all the proper names in the puzzle, which at some point some people will no doubt be along to complain about. 

WELL DONE, Mr. Royce.

A Thursday puzzle that wasn't a struggle, with a few unknowns (a bank and an opera singer I've never heard of) that were helped by the crosses. 

I'm glad the rebus squares weren't shaded, that would have made it too easy. In any case, it was the perfect challenge level I needed today. 

Plus I learned about a new critter, the STONEFLY.
ü¶ü
Oh goodie, a rebus. Now I can skip the puzzle & go back to my Alice Munro book. Many thanks for the break.
Easy Thursday.  Half my average time but a couple minutes off my personal best‚Ä¶

Fancy!

I should not be surprised that, when clue after clue gets me nowhere on a Thursday, there‚Äôs a revealer that points to just as many rebi. 

Yes, that‚Äôs how I plural it up.
first time in ages that i got the ha-ha without looking it up.

It didn't take too long to figure out we were missing a few letters here and there. Thanks to [EAR]NER and the revealer, it was obvious where to look for the rebuses. So, the puzzle was a bit easy for a Thursday, but it still had some tricky spots along with the rebuses. I was not familiar with the STONE FLY or JESSYE Norman, so depended on crosses for those.

Nice one, Royce, and thanks.

Fun rebus puzzle! The clues containing rebuses were very fairly clued. That combined with their predictable placement on the ‚ÄúWALLS‚Äù meant this puzzle came together fairly quickly.

Well conceived and constructed in my book. Bravo!
hope mr shortz recovers soon we need him. year used three times in one puzzle come on.
Ok, this is probably my favorite of the often troublesome Thursday puzzles - more smiles than frowns in working thru it. It was, dare I say, fun!

I was hoping that all four themed entries would have the form of a repeated/rhyming phrase (HEARTOHEART, WEARANDTEAR, HEARYEHEARYE) ... So BEARSTEARNS was a bit disappointing. 

On the other hand I can't think of any suitable EAR-repeating phrases. "Nearanddear" is close but lacks a letter. So I'll take old Bear Stearns I guess

Cute theme but far too easy for a Thursday. Would have suited a Tuesday nicely.
Note to one poster: some of us do know Jessye Norman and are the richer for having heard her sing.
I did not enjoy this puzzle.

Fun rebus puzzle today, and one in which I actually used the revealer.

I liked the two four-letter canal locales, the rhyme at 43D and 44D, and the callback at 31A to today's Mini.

In other words, it wasn't just the rebuses today.

Thanks!

Well constructed. Enjoyable. No indicators where the rebuses are. All in all, a very good crossword puzzle.

I'm glad to learn that MENORAH has a broader meaning than I thought.

I'm also glad to hear that 'haut' and EAU are pronounced the same. French has eluded me, although I can still repeat the American pledge of allegiance in French, because I learned it in elementary school in Massachusetts. I should research this -- I've often wondered whether my memory of it is perfect. (I'm sure it's not.) 

French's evasive man≈ìuvres within my life seem odd, because I love languages, and, since high school, I've had a backburner desire to read 'The Stranger' as Camus wrote it. Now that I live close to eastern Canada, perhaps I'll explore French further.

As a dead tree solver with a micro-point gel pen, I cringed at the thought of having to solve a Thursday online. I'm a fast typist, but not when I'm jumping around a puzzle and not sure of how to orient the cursor to fill in the across and down clues. That takes practice!

But I spent 15 hours - no exaggeration - installing a new router and getting my PC online. I've done this many times before, but obviously bought the wrong router this time. Then another 3 hours on the phone with Apple trying to get my devices online. Ya think I could then print the puzzle? Nah, now the printer won't connect. 

With no other choice, I resigned myself to a miserable slog. Fortunately, this had to be one of the easiest rebuses (rebi?) I've ever encountered, and it almost filled itself in. It probably helped that I got the revealer with only the first two letters filled in, and it sort of gave itself away. It also helped that I knew I needed to fill in only the first letter of the rebus. All in all, great practice for the weekend puzzles, since I may not get that printer working as fast as I hope to.

A gentle rebus. 
Clues were a tad on easy side so the 
locations of the EARS was so easy to see.

Even before the revealer!

Expecting some anti-rebus converts on this beauty.

‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

Fun puzzle. Typical slow start for me with not a whole lot on first pass, but then I focused on working the reveal and once I did, thing fell together pretty smoothly. Actually ended up a bit below my average Thursday time. Roundabout answer history search today led to a Sunday puzzle from January 25, 1981 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title: "Crazy Rhythms." A couple of sample theme answers: ALCOTTSCHILLUNGOTRHYTHM ILOVEMYWIFEBUTOHEUCLID Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/25/1981&g=40&d=A ..

With likely the most guessable revealer I've seen I filled in the center last night and saved the sides for this morning.  Sort of like eating an *oreo*?  Then with sharper little grey cells I had a lot of fun working on the 4 downs with no crosses.  All made for a very satisfying solve.  

Also noticed all the "J's" walking around.   

Congrats on your Thursday debut, it was a good one.

Outlander is an awesome series but the books are even better! (especially if you have Sam Heughan in your mind when reading about Jamie) I recommend listening to the Outlander books on tape. The reader, Davina Porter, is fabulous.

Ahem! I came to say that Clinton's FOLLY--aka the Erie Canal--wasn't "located" in Erie, unless you mean that its terminus was into Lake Erie. But not at the city of Erie (PA); it ran from "Albany to Bu-u-ffalo" as we learned in third-grade music class. But in fact-checking for this post, I learned that Buffalo is in Erie County, NY, so I guess there's that. But, so far as I know, it didn't run through Asbury Park, NJ: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SDvYBCZwMIk The "French homonyms" clue reminded me of this bit of constrained writing, by George Starbuck, even if it's a little forced, with references to bygone politicians and obscure literary figures:

The two moments I remember most: ‚Ä¢ Filling in THE WALLS HAVE EARS off of the first two and last three letters. Kazaam! And ‚Ä¶ OMG, what a lovely phrase! ‚Ä¢ My brain shouting ‚ÄúIVEY!‚Äù upon seeing [Phil in the Poker Hall of Fame], and me bewildered and stunned that I knew this, not knowing from where. I see he‚Äôs shown up a few times over the years in NYT puzzle, but man, the things we have lying in wait in the nooks of our brains! Thrilling solve for me. As rarely happens on Thursday, it was as though I woke up in Royce‚Äôs head, just started filling in answers, waiting for stuckness, but no, rub be gone! Along the way, lovely perks, like the scintillating answer OPALESCE, and lovely clue [Odd, duck, maybe?] for DECOY. Speaking of memorable things, take a look at the grid design of his Saturday, 7/25/20 puzzle ‚Äì ( https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2020/07/25 ). Elegant, gorgeous, and wow! Royce, you repeatedly hit my happy button today. Thank you so much for making this!

Yes, a bit easy for a Thursday, but I enjoyed it quite a bit. 

Folks sure get a little bent out of shape in the Comments section. Not every puzzle can live up to your own personal idea of a "perfect puzzle". That's a ridiculous expectation to have.

Perhaps "personal constructor" will someday be as viable an occupation as "personal chef". 

Congratulations on the publication of your first Thursday puzzle, Royce!

Another fun one today. For some reason, each of the J crosses made me stumble, and it took me an oddly long minute to realize that tEARANDwEAR isn‚Äôt a thing. Otherwise, a breezy rebus with a spectacular spanner of a revealer. Thanks, Royce Ferguson & eds.!

BRAVO, Royce!  This was fun even after the trick was quickly made obvious.  I especially enjoyed all the J's.
I had a brief moment of thinking "Little pitchers" but clearly that was too long.
Anyone else disappointed by 32A when it wasn't FRED?  There is always a tug at my heart-strings, because we could have used more than 77 years of Fred Rogers in our lives....sigh.

Now to see how many of us TSK-TSKed about the botched clue at 61A....Just "Noted canal" would have been plenty.  "I had a mule; her name was Sal...."  

WordPerfect is denying access to a file it claims is "read only" and I can't get into my recipe!  DHubby is heading to the eye doctor with a minor emergency, so my personal geek squad is deserting me.  Prayers EARnestly solicited...

Oh, dEAR. I love rebuses, but I bet you'll get an EARful.

My only "hunh" is for the singular form of ARREAR. Never ran across that before. Yes, Barry, I'll go check the dictionary.

First Thursday I've solved with no hints!!

I know it may have been a bit easier for regular solvers but I think changing it up tricky-yet-approachable puzzles such as this one do a lot to grow the community. 

Fun puzzle!

HARVEY crossing IVEY crossing ROY
Oof (says this non USian)

For some reason the French clue immediately implanted a D'yer Mak'er EARworm in my head, but spelled all wrong
EAU, HAUT, OWE, OWE, HAUT, EAU,
YOU DON'T HAVE TO GEAU-HAUT

Enjoy!
Two canals within all the ears. This was a breeze, but then  I like puzzles with rebuses, they add an extra dimension sort of.

Harvey and Seeley Mudd and others in that family are worth looking into. They did a lot of good things with their money.

I haven‚Äôt had cr√™pes Suzette since somewhere around 1982 but now I want some.

As all of my iris are now in bloom, I wanted iridesce, but opalesce will do fine. Both lovely words.
"Pregap"?

For those of us not apparently in the known universe, I wonder how many thought of TED and Dusty Bin.

Maybe 321

Congrats, Mr. Ferguson on such a clever puzzle! I got the revealer pretty quickly once I had a few crossings and plugged in HEARYEHEARYE right away. I love Thursday puzzles and I was cruising through this one until I got to the SW corner. I‚Äôm supposed to know Hall of Fame poker players now? And Harvey Mudd? So, I had a couple lookups but finished under my average time. Favorite clue: ‚ÄúOdd duck, perhaps?‚Äù Anyone know if ‚ÄúNoogie‚Äù has been in a puzzle before?
I often find Thursday puzzles frustrating, but I enjoyed this one!  Thanks! ü•Ç

Enjoyable Thursday , rare for this rebus fearing traditionalist. TIL about stone flies, it turns out most do not spend their whole lives in water, but one in Lake Tahoe does. Cannot comment on the French homophone issue, I wish could speak that beautiful language. Also enjoyed opalesce . Nice start to my Thursday out her in Cali.

Okay, let's start again with the strand on Strands.

Strands #88
‚ÄúPump it up!‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üü°üîµüîµüîµ

Avoid any spoilery comments until we're past three comments, below the fold, please.
The theme/title sent me off on several tangents before it finally clicked.

Love this! There‚Äôs no better way to start off a Thursday than a rebus puzzle. Thank you Royce!

PSA: As tempting as it is to respond to the trolls to set them straight, in doing so you‚Äôre giving them exactly what they want. Trolling is a major source of entertainment for middle aged men still living with their parents. Ignore them. 

Do not, however, ignore an emu. In fact, never let them out of your sight. You do not want to be kicked by an emu. Trust me on this one.

Loved it!  The perfect rebus puzzle: impossible before you figure out the trick and very smooth sailing thereafter.  Because once you have the revealer, you know exactly where the rebus answers will go -- a huge help!

I had the advantage of having often heard the expression THE WALLS HAVE EARS -- which, if you haven't, will make the puzzle tougher.  Because I had ACL??? and wanted ACL TEAR, as soon as WALL came in at 7D, I wrote in the expression and I wrote in the TEAR rebus.

I had wanted WEAR AND TEAR at 1D from the get-go, but couldn't make it work.  And now I could.  I decided to go the the other "walls" and try to get them all without crosses.  And HEAR YE, HEAR YE, I did.  All 3 of them.  I was helped by the fact that BEAR STEARNS used to be my broker before it folded.

I live for double-rebus answers like these!  Very well-chosen themers and a smoothly-made grid.

One small critique.  To ARREAR:  ALCOHOLS would like to gift you with its "S".  It doesn't need it and you do.  But a small price to pay for a really enjoyable puzzle.
I write the rebus answer in the square with my pen on my printout.  Easy-peasy!

"I love the smell of NATURE in the morning" was my first thought.  Boy was I wrong!  Easiest rebus puzzle I've seen in a long time.  Solvers wary of Thursdays could give this one a try and see what fun they're missing.

Good theme + Good revealer + Good rebuses = Excellent Thursday puzzle!

I was able to guess the big reveal at 7-D early on, and to infer its implications for the puzzle.  Nevertheless, a fine puzzle!
Royce Ferguson has constructed a truly entertaining puzzle.  Thank you!

Still doing puzzle but had to laugh that having first gotten the theme answer right away, my first ‚Äúear‚Äù attempt was in the SW corner. Which is where I spent far too much time trying to fit in the ‚Äúear‚Äù of iridescence.‚Äù

This wasn‚Äôt a difficult puzzle, but I had more trouble with it than others did. 

I jumped around a bit, having 2D ‚ÄúFacing a judge‚Äù as ‚ÄúOn trial‚Äù (which, even as I typed it, I realized could be IN COURT). And I misspelled 35A JESSey, thought I know who she was. 53A was iridESCE for too long. 

It wasn‚Äôt until B[EAR] ST[EAR]NS that the rebuses clicked. When I got the revealer, I first put the rebuses in the squares along the left edge so that they were symmetrical with those on the right. 

Thanks for the fin, Mr. Ferguson!
Love this puzzle! Thanks, Royce Ferguson!
Incredibly beautiful singing by Jessye Norman, Mythodea with Greek subtitles. I don‚Äôt know Greek but NASA uses the music https://youtu.be/aNbarKaDwv8

During the first week or so of Joel Fagliano's reign, everyone seemed to complain about the difficulty of the puzzles.

During the last week or so, everyone seems to be complaining about how the puzzles are too easy.

Isn't life interesting?

I love the smell of rebus in the morning, it smells like...victory.

Also, the sounds of LOONs in the afternoon, which I got to hear last weekend in the North Country. Pretty much off the grid up there, so the streak of 100+ is ended. Oh well, not really bothered.

Patrick of NYC said earlier,

hope mr shortz recovers soon we need him. year used three times in one puzzle come on.


Funny.  When Will was well, there were a slew of comments about how he was washed up and should retire.

Now that he's not in his chair, everyone wishes he were back.

People are funny.
Thanks, Mr Ferguson.  Entertaining.  The acne clue was a smile.
The Stonefly/Jessye crossing was an absolute Natick. Brutal. Otherwise easy

I loved this puzzle, partly because I caught on early. There may be complaints of ‚Äútoo easy‚Äù but it was just right as far as I‚Äôm concerned, and I thank Royce Ferguson for a terrific theme that still got me out for my morning walk before it gets too hot. I saw the rebus early too, with HEART TO HEART, and the revealer at 7D was one of my first bits of fill, so that was a big help.
I have the entire puzzle solved. I just don't know how to get the three letters into the one box. Could someone inform me how to do this?
Just did the May bonus puzzle today. I have never looked up so much stuff in my life!! LOL Hopefully some of it will stick with me.

A lovely entertaining puzzle. I‚Äôve learned to appreciate the rebus grid over the years, but today I thoroughly enjoyed it. It helped that I got the revealer straight away; plus I just knew 1D had to be WEAR AND TEAR, so that helped. 
The bank was the last to fall, being unknown to me, plus live before JIVE, but otherwise a smooth, entertaining fill.  Nicely done.

How old is everyone that participates daily? I‚Äôm 31 years old and just can‚Äôt handle Thursday through Sunday puzzles without Google. Mostly thrown off by old phrases that no longer occupy the daily vernacular, and/or historical/pop culture references from before my time. Hopefully this skill comes with age! lol

There was a time I really hated rebuses (rebii?). That was before I learned to think a little more out of the box. Well, in this case, more In the box. Now I really like them and have come to almost expect them on Thursdays. A well done puzzle today.

Once I knew to expect it (I am fairly new to the NYT crossword), I love a good rebus puzzle. There was an impressive variety of EAR words on display here, especially with the added constraint that they had to be the start/end of the entry for the acrosses, though it was a bit disappointing to see TEAR show up no fewer than three times. Not much to do but grin and BEAR it.

I struggled more than usual with the non-themed fill. I‚Äôm sure poor sleep is partly to blame, but there were also more proper nouns than I personally like to see, particularly crossing one another. DECOY gave me a sensible chuckle.

I‚Äôve only been solving daily for a few months (but am working my way through the archive) so it may be premature to ask, but at what point will I ever remember that rebuses are an option?!
I actually thought of the answers to most of the rebus-ed(?) clues, but moved on because they didn‚Äôt fit. Rebus didn‚Äôt even occur to me. Why!? Headsmack, facepalm, etc. Ugh.
Bravo!

really fantastic puzzle - loved the theme and the revealer... fun solve all the way through.
i wish there were a few less proper nouns, or at the very least... stop having them cross each other. EDITORS - you consistently receive feedback to not have propers cross in these comments... and yet you consistently ignore this. WHY? this is not an unsolvable nor impossible request from your audience and your consistent refusal is disrespectful, to be honest.

So, let me get the rules straight. 

If I submit a comment expressing my disappointment with the day's puzzle---no attacks or hateful language, just a simple opinion---will it get deleted (again), unless I include an explanatory essay?

Because I don't want to write an essay for every puzzle I find sub-par. But I hope the editors value my feedback.

Oh this was fun fun! About halfway through everything finally started to click. I erased all my first guesses on the left side and redid everything with a new mindset and it all fell into place. Really hit the spot mentally LOL! Love ASPECT as an answer.
Hands down, this was one of my most favorite puzzles in recent memory. The execution was stellar and so creative. Well done!

This is about as perfect a puzzle as I can imagine. Lots of fun fill, but I suspected something was up in the southeast corner when I couldn‚Äôt fit anything in for Unpaid debt. I‚Äôve learned to be patient and just keep going, while staying alert for a rebus. This is Thursday after all. Once I got the long revealer, the jig was up and I romped through the rest. I especially like when the theme helps keep solve other clues. The last to fall was EARNER. Thanks for the great fun!

Once I got the rebus (early on), this puzzle went from a Thursday difficulty to a Tuesday. 

I‚Äôm rested up and ready for Friday and Saturday.

Software critique. On my Mac, I completed the grid and used autocheck, which indicated I had gotten all answers correctly. But the timer was and still is running, because I had missed four rebi. I misunderstood the gag. So I should have a chance to fix those and finish the puzzle.

For some reason the puzzle won‚Äôt let me enter the rebus ‚ÄòEAR‚Äô for ARREARS/STEARNS or EARTH/TEAR. Has anyone on this thread ever had a glitch like that before? It also won‚Äôt let me delete the letter I had in the rebus box for each of those sections on the puzzle. I tried closing the app and that didn‚Äôt fix it.
What a fun Thursday, congrats on the clever construct. Definitely a bit on the easy side for a Thursday, once you figure out that "the ears have it." üôÇ

As the day went on today I had a thought about this puzzle. We all know that rebus puzzles almost always appear on Thursdays or Sundays, even though when you go over to xwordinfo you can see they have appeared on other days as well. In particular, if you look at Monday rebus puzzles they seem to involve just one or a couple of squares, often just using an Arabic numeral as an entry. Wednesday rebus puzzles are a little more varied. One that caught my eye was 3/4/2009 by C.W. Stuart, obviously with Will as editor.  This puzzle had eight identical rebus squares placed symmetrically around the sides of the grid each reading IN/OUT. The revealer was smack in the middle of the grid, ‚ÄúChoice for a dog, as well as a hint to this puzzles theme.‚Äù Answer: INOROUT. A perfect, easy rebus puzzle to run on a Wednesday. I think Joel lost out on a great chance to run today‚Äôs puzzle yesterday, I think it would have received rave reviews.

Yeah, NOOGIES are playful, but I remember them as kind of hurting.

Of course I am something of a WIMP.

A simple offering:
Fill is not content.

Gaga and Swift and Cher are all potential fill.
When clued, they become content -
‚Äúcrazy over‚Äù  ‚Äúchimney bird‚Äù ‚ÄúFrench dearie‚Äù
vs.
‚Äúsinger this‚Äù, ‚Äúsinger that‚Äù, ‚Äúsinger the other‚Äù

Any grid offers multiple fills that can or could have been clued
pop culture
terminological trivia
acronym anagram abbreviation

Step back and simply ask the question of the puzzle itself: how is this puzzle presented?

If I play the pitches c-e-g-a together
as a classical musician, I am playing an A minor 7 in first inversion, or an A 65.
as a jazz musician, I am playing the same notes but it is a C6 chord.

The secret, says Celie, is in the sauce.
Today‚Äôs earworm, brought to you in by the 1980s: https://tinyurl.com/hadbdsh4

This is the first time I've done a puzzle with a rebus and actually filled in the revealer and the rebuses without any help or hints! I get the hype now, how satisfyingg.

I hated them before because it never even crossed my mind when or how to try a rebus, leaving me stuck and mad. But this one kinda naturally came about which put a smile on my face :)

Am I the only person who thinks a rebus is not a crossword? There are many interesting and respectable forms of wordplay and these are written in their various forms. When labeled you can pick what you want to play.
Best Thursday time! But this was an easy one.

My my my- a puzzle like this can OPALESCE on a hard day. Thank you Royce, for the SMASH of a crossword with many an EAR hiding in the PREGAPs. 

There are few things more satisfying for me than solving a rebus on my own. The revealer was delightful and not taxingly difficult, which I appreciated. 

Absolutely loved the clue for ACNE. I originally had Exams for 63a but when I was clued into the shenanigans of 36d things clicked into place- just like my favorite kind of puzzles do. Bravo! Or shall I say, WELLDONE.

@David Connell 
My Saeva Mater had a Seeley G. Mudd library--one of many across the country. It. like the rest of the campus, was constructed on rather swampy ground. The lore was that, in its planning, the architects took into account the weight of the building, but not that of the books; thus, the entire edifice was, well, sinking in  . . .

Not to be confused with Harcourt Fenton Mudd, of Star Trek fame.

How would you, David, describe the difference between opalesce and iridesce?

@Bill - iridesce comes from Iris, goddess of the rainbow whose name transfers to the flowers, my very favorites. Both the rainbow and the O‚ÄôKeeffe parts of the flower show many colors, but in a gentle effusive way. Opalesce comes from opal, the shimmering gemstone with shine that either is multi-colored or not. So a gem-quality opal is iridescent, but a lower-quality one is only opalescent.

Then we have the sapphires with their asterisms, the adamantine luster of diamonds, the vitreous qualities of rubies, the pearlescence ‚Ä¶

Is that you, O Smaug the Magnificent? I was lost in a dream of Erebor‚Ä¶

digging too greedily and too deep‚Ä¶

b mateer, 

Crossword puzzles that contain 
more than one letter in a square 
or symbols that are not letters in squares 
still cross words, so whether you like 
or dislike the idea of squares containing 
other than one letter, they are crosswords. 

And there have been rebuses 
in NYT Crosswords since 1954.

@Barry Ancona 

I think you're the perfect guy to ask this question.

Back in the pre-internet days, the only way to find out if you were right on a crossword was to wait until the next day to see the solution published.

But how did they do that with rebuses?  The solutions were kind of small anyway, and the letters in a rebus must have been miniscule.

A gentle Thursday rebus made for a pleasant solve and I‚Äôm smiling ear to ear.  I thought I knew what was up at ACLTEAR, but waited until HEARYEHEARYE to search out the rebus squares.  Any puzzle that clues OPALESCE is ok in my book.  

I also liked the span of musical clues ranging from jazz through opera to pop/rock. For those who enjoy opera, JESSYE Norman‚Äôs voice was a national treasure.  While I don‚Äôt consider myself an opera buff, I learned to appreciate the music through forced exposure in my youth.  My father listened to opera all the time and always had Texaco‚Äôs Saturday Afternoon at the Opera blaring on the radio on Saturdays.  At the time I considered it cruel and unusual punishment, but a lot of it stuck with me. 

And what‚Äôs up with having two Christmas themed answers one atop the other in the middle of a puzzle released in June.  Nothing wrong with that per se, just an oddity that struck me.

I've never commented here before. I thought I'd give it a shot today because I just scored my first 100 day streak AND had a rebus puzzle that didn't make me want to scream!  Great puzzle, thank you!

It‚Äôs nice when working through the NW corner reveals the theme. Rather easy, but figuring out a rebus is always a winner.  I was a little disappointed that the same word was used repeatedly in theme answers without being specifically required to repeat because of the theme. But anyway. Fun puzzle.

Didn‚Äôt help me that ‚ÄúTake it down a notch‚Äù also fit the theme answer‚Ä¶ which I thought I was very clever to guess right away with only the first T crossing. So even while subsequent crossings weren‚Äôt working on that column I was looking for Thursday-puzzle-solving ways to bend the answers ‚Äúdown a notch‚Äù to make them work. When the H for OAHU was all the way at the bottom I thought ‚Äútoo many notches‚Äù.
The asymetricity of the rebus squares caused me some early difficulty but eventually I figured it out. Good fun from a clever constructor!
Such a great puzzle! Fun, witty, clever. I loved the little touches like SUEZ and ERIE (naturally I had ERIE in the first slot before the crosses disabused me of that notion).

Good lawd, the south west almost did me in.

So many names and then the trickiness.

Just barely solved the puzzle without help, so of course it was a good puzzle.

But my phone is now announcing every letter I tap even though it refuses to do dictation any more.  I can do without the constant "improvements" I've been suffering through lately.
Very fun Thursday! A rebus puzzle where I don‚Äôt have to look up any hints is very rare. Enjoyed this one a lot!
Well, that was utterly delightful. Thank you!

As is so often the case for me, I am late to the party.  No doubt everyone has moved on to (or even solved) the Friday puzzle by now. It occurs to me that perhaps ‚Äúrebus‚Äù derives ‚Äî or should derive ‚Äî from Erebus: a place of darkness in the underworld on the way to Hades(town).  I would merely add that EAR is one more notable location for a canal.

'Haut' and EAU are indeed pronounced the same.

I didn't get *all* the way through the comments before mine, so this may have been mentioned earlier. But wow! What a lot of J's in this puzzle!! And a few Z entries, too -- without checking, it seems a great case for a pangram.

But wow! Those J's!! My understanding (from the Wordplay community, of course) is that J is the most (or one of the most) difficult letters to include in a puzzle. This puzzle has a stellar number of them, and they're not even related to the theme or theme answers! 

4 squares/8 words beginning with J. Very nice. Juicy, even!
